name: ASRS v1.1
summary: 18-item adult ADHD screener with Part A (6 items) and Part B (12 items).
description: The ASRS v1.1 is a validated screening tool for adult ADHD aligned with DSM criteria. Part A (items 1-6) is the primary screener, while Part B (items 7-18) provides additional symptom context.
purpose: Screen for adult ADHD and assess symptom patterns across inattention and hyperactivity-impulsivity domains.

items.text: How often do you have trouble wrapping up the final details of a project, once the challenging parts have been done?
How often do you have difficulty getting things in order when you have to do a task that requires organization?
How often do you have problems remembering appointments or obligations?
When you have a task that requires a lot of thought, how often do you avoid or delay getting started?
How often do you fidget or squirm with your hands or feet when you have to sit down for a long time?
How often do you feel overly active and compelled to do things, like you were driven by a motor?
How often do you make careless mistakes when you have to work on a boring or difficult project?
How often do you have difficulty keeping your attention when you are doing boring or repetitive work?
How often do you have difficulty concentrating on what people say to you, even when they are speaking to you directly?
How often do you misplace or have difficulty finding things at home or at work?
How often are you distracted by activity or noise around you?
How often do you leave your seat in meetings or other situations in which you are expected to remain seated?
How often do you feel restless or fidgety?
How often do you have difficulty unwinding and relaxing when you have time to yourself?
How often do you find yourself talking too much when you are in social situations?
When you're in a conversation, how often do you find yourself finishing the sentences of the people you are talking to, before they can finish them themselves?
How often do you have difficulty waiting your turn in situations when turn taking is required?
How often do you interrupt others when they are busy?

clinical_interpretations.Low: Your scores indicate minimal ADHD symptoms. Part A score ≤9 and total score ≤30 are both below clinical thresholds, consistent with typical adult functioning without clinically significant ADHD symptoms.
clinical_interpretations.Mild to Moderate: Your scores are in the mild to moderate range. If Part A is 10-13 (below diagnostic threshold) but total score approaches 40+ (79th percentile), clinical evaluation may still be warranted as this pattern can be diagnostically informative.
clinical_interpretations.High: Your scores indicate clinically significant ADHD symptoms. Part A scores 14-17 meet the diagnostic threshold, and/or total scores 40-49 exceed the 79th percentile where most individuals with ADHD score. Professional evaluation is recommended.
clinical_interpretations.Very High: Your scores indicate severe ADHD symptoms. Part A scores ≥18 or total scores ≥50 represent very high symptom levels that are strongly consistent with ADHD diagnosis and require comprehensive clinical evaluation.

sections.title: About the ASRS v1.1
sections.text: The Adult ADHD Self-Report Scale (ASRS) v1.1 is a validated screening tool based on DSM criteria. Part A (items 1-6) is the most predictive for ADHD screening, while Part B (items 7-18) provides additional symptom severity information across inattention and hyperactivity-impulsivity domains.

sections.title: Instructions
sections.text: For each item, choose how often the problem has occurred over the past 6 months. Please answer each question as honestly as possible based on your recent experiences.

sections.title: Scoring and Interpretation
sections.text: Part A scores of 14 or higher suggest symptoms consistent with ADHD and warrant professional evaluation. The assessment provides scores for overall symptom severity and specific symptom domains including inattention and hyperactivity-impulsivity.

psychometric_properties.validation: Validated against DSM-IV and DSM-5 ADHD criteria

clinical_alerts.adhd_screening: Part A scores ≥14 indicate positive ADHD screening and recommend professional evaluation

limitations: Screening tool only — not diagnostic by itself
Requires clinical judgment and comprehensive evaluation for diagnosis
May not capture all ADHD presentations or comorbid conditions
